docs.lead_paragraph: MARKETS Exuberance Dashed, Exuberance Regained Intel sneezed and the stock market caught a cold, or was it pneumonia? Neither, it seems. Just a one-day panic attack. The Dow industrials, which had been rising at a torrid rate lately, skidded 1.11 percent on Thursday, reacting to Intel's announcement late Wednesday that its earnings would not meet analysts' expectations. Intel's shares tumbled 12.5 percent, but they gained more than 3 percent on Friday to end the week at $78.125. The selling pressure moved first through the technology sector and then to the broader market. But on Friday, traders were more optimistic, with the Dow industrials ending the week at 8,569.39, up 23.67. The Nasdaq composite, however, slipped 17.02 for the week, closing at 1,753.49.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wendy Scribner spent 10 years writing her dissertation, typing it at night in a railroad flat on East Ninth Street while her two small boys were growing up in a windowless middle room. It was the pinched, obsessed life of an underground character in a novel by Dostoyevsky, one of her favorite authors. But the sacrifices for her Ph.D., which she received from New York University in 1989, did not bring her the respected professorial career she had craved. Yes, she teaches -- at two colleges, in fact -- but at 56 she is an adjunct professor, a ''part-time'' teacher who like thousands of other adjuncts in New York City ekes out a living working full time by stitching together jobs at two, three, and four campuses and maintaining a strong stomach for indignities.

headline.main: After Her Ph.D., the Scavenger's Life; Trying to Turn a Patchwork of Part-Time Jobs Into an Academic Career

docs.abstract: Interview with Wendy Scribner, 56, on disjointed life of adjunct professor in New York City, a 'part-time' teacher who like thousands of other adjuncts in New York City ekes out a living working full time by stitching together jobs at two, three and four campuses and maintaining strong stomach for indignities; Scribner's career is a thing of shreds and patches, of taking subway to one campus and hiking across Brooklyn Bridge to another, of teaching remedial, summer and evening classes most professors shun and scavenging thankless paid-by-the-hour jobs like grading placement examinations; although she teaches 16 credits a semester, she has no office, not even a desk; no pension and a salary that in most years is less than that of a starting elementary school teacher; photos; charts (L)
docs.snippet: Wendy Scribner spent 10 years writing her dissertation, typing it at night in a railroad flat on East Ninth Street while her two small boys were growing up in a windowless middle room. It was the pinched, obsessed life of an underground character in...

docs.lead_paragraph: CHANGE, change, change. Those three words account for the longevity of the Wartburg, a Mount Vernon fixture for 132 years. ''Our ability to change to meet the needs of the community has been our strength,'' said Dr. Dale G. Gatz, president and chief operating officer of the Wartburg. Dr. Gatz, a Lutheran minister, was named to his current post seven years ago, just when major changes to the Wartburg were in the planning stage.

headline.main: The Wartburg Alters Its Health Care

docs.abstract: Wartburg, small nursing home in Mount Vernon, NY, has been transformed into large medical complex of on-site health care services; center will eventually become first adult-care, out-patient complex in region offering consolidated health care services under one roof; Dr Dale G Gatz, president and chief operating officer, comments; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: William Abranowicz, a photographer who racks up around 200,000 miles on airplanes every year, is living proof that frequent fliers face other dangers than plane crashes and the American Airlines dinner calzone: ''I can get off a plane and have giant red marks on each side of my nose, develop a dry scalp, my skin will be inflamed. My skin freaks out.'' Yikes! It turns out that very frequent fliers might be earning more than platinum status. They could be collecting conditions like ''economy-class syndrome,'' and suffering symptoms ranging from flatulence to death.

headline.main: Is There a Doctor On the Plane?

docs.abstract: Brian Alexander article on health hazards faced by very frequent fliers; notes shortage of studies of long-term effects; list of frequent problems; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN he was starting out as a standup comedian in the 1960's, Woody Allen joked about being expelled from college for cheating on a philosophy exam: ''I looked within the soul of the boy sitting next to me,'' he said. Three decades (and 30 years of personal psychotherapy) later, Mr. Allen still sprinkles his movie scripts with references to philosophers like Kierkegaard and Kant, as well as to psychoanalysts like Freud.

headline.main: The Nation: I Bill, Therefore I Am; Philosophers Ponder a Therapy Gold Mine

docs.abstract: Small but growing number of American philosophers take leaf out of psychotherapy book and open private practices, offering therapy based on idea that solutions to personal and ethical problems may be found within 2,500-year-old body of philosophical discourse; drawing; Prof Lou Marinoff, who charges $100 a session, says his counseling rejects psychotherapy's 'medical' view in favor of humanistic approach stressing dialogue and self-reflection (M)
